Welcome to the Hyperledger Wiki!

Hyperledger is a consortium of communities which works on two different levels.

  1. Projects focus on implementations of blockchain frameworks and modules
  2. Working groups focus on different aspects, typically independent of any specific implementation

Projects

Frameworks

Name Status CII Badge Description
Burrow Incubation 0% Permissioned Ethereum smart-contract blockchain
Fabric Active Distributed ledger in Golang
Indy Incubation 0% Distributed ledger purpose-built for decentralized identity
Iroha Active Distributed ledger in C++
Sawtooth Active Distributed ledger in Python

Modules

Name Status CII Badge Supports (Potentially) Description
Cello Incubation 0% Fabric, (Sawtooth, Iroha) Blockchain management/operation
Cello Analytics Incubation 0% Cello Blockchain analytics
Composer Incubation 0% Fabric, (Sawtooth, Iroha) Development framework/tools for building Blockchain business networks
Explorer Incubation 0% Fabric, (Sawtooth, Iroha) Blockchain Web UI
Fabric Chaintool Active 0% Fabric Chaincode packaging for Fabric
Fabric SDK Py Active 0% Fabric Fabric SDK in Python
Fabric SDK Go Incubation 0% Fabric Fabric SDK in Golang
Quilt Incubation 0% An interoperability solution for blockchains, DLTs and other types of ledgers

Community Working Groups (WG)

  • How To Connect with Hyperledger Projects and WGs
  • Technical Steering Committee (TSC)
  • Architecture Working Group
  • Requirements Working Group
  • Identity Working Group
  • Performance and Scale Working Group
  • Protocol Working Group
  • Whitepaper Working Group
  • Healthcare Working Group
  • Technical Working Group China (TWG-China, 大中华区技术工作组)

Governing Documents of the Hyperledger Technical Community

  • Charter of the Hyperledger Project overall.
  • Scope of planned projects covering core ledger functionality.
  • Code of Conduct for all project workspaces.
  • Project Lifecycle defines stages of projects within Hyperledger, from Proposal → Incubation → Active.
  • Project Incubation Exit Criteria required before a project is declared Active and production-ready.
  • Release Taxonomy provides guidelines for release and pre-release versioning and tags.
  • Proposal Template for a new Hyperleger project community.
  • Current Proposals for new projects at Hyperledger.
  • Working Group Charter Template
  • Security Bug Handling Process
  • Quarterly Project Updates

How We Communicate

  • Email - most development communication is on archived mailing lists by project area.
  • RocketChat (Slack alternative) - is where daily conversations and questions happen. You will need a Linux Foundation ID to login to our Rocket Chat instance.
  • RocketChat Channels - lists all chat rooms available.

Meeting & Event Schedules

  • Calendar of Public Meetings - where Working Groups have regular calls/chats to plan.
  • We encourage people to run their own Meetups about Hyperledger and our projects.

Security

  • Security
  • Security Team
  • CII Badge Security Section
  • Static and Dynamic Analysis Tools
  • Learning: Designing and Building Secure Software
  • Learning: Crypto Best Practices
  • Learning: Strategies for Secure Delivery

Miscellaneous

  • Participating in the Community
  • Frequently-Asked-Questions, or FAQ
  • Gerrit or Github - is used for submitting PRs and managing code reviews and checkins.
  • Jira or Github - is used for submitting bugs.
  • Presentations
  • Hackfest
  • Slack Archives
